terms.shortDef: A user, also referred to as an ArcGIS user, is an individual who has an ArcGIS account and uses it to sign in and interact with an ArcGIS product, portal, or application. A user's identity is authenticated and their ability to interact with ArcGIS resources is determined by the privileges associated with their account.
terms.name: user

terms.shortDef: A hosted table is a type of hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings of a non-spatial feature layer in a feature service.
terms.name: hosted table

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS subscription is a free or paid plan that defines the capabilities of an ArcGIS account and the method of billing for the consumption of location services.
terms.name: ArcGIS subscription

terms.shortDef: A simple route is the lowest cost path that visits all stops specified by the user in the order they are provided.
terms.name: simple route

terms.shortDef: An analysis variable is a data field name that defines which data to query and return from the GeoEnrichment service.
terms.name: analysis variable

terms.shortDef: The cloud is a network of remote servers hosted on the internet to store, manage, and process data.
terms.name: cloud

terms.shortDef: Spatial analysis services are services that perform geometry and statistical analyses on feature and raster data.
terms.name: spatial analysis services

terms.shortDef: A layer is a reference to a collection of geographic data that is used to access and display data. The data for layers are typically provided by the basemap layer service and data services.
terms.name: layer

terms.shortDef: A spatial analysis service, also known as a feature analysis service, is a service used to perform spatial analysis operations on feature data such as finding, comparing, summarizing, analyzing patterns, and calculating geometries.
terms.name: spatial analysis service

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS API is a web, native, game engine, or scripting API that has advanced mapping and spatial analysis capabilities and can be used to access ArcGIS services. ArcGIS APIs are designed to work optimally with the ArcGIS system and provide the most advanced GIS features and the highest performance possible.
terms.name: ArcGIS API

terms.shortDef: A vector tile package, also known as a VTPK, is a read-only data file containing static tiles of vector data.
terms.name: vector tile package

terms.shortDef: A feature layer (server-side) is a spatially-enabled table in a feature service. All features in a feature layer share the same geometry type and set of fields.
terms.name: feature layer (server-side)

terms.shortDef: Subsurface navigation is the action of zooming, panning, and tilting a 3D scene from a viewpoint located below the earth's surface.
terms.name: subsurface navigation

terms.shortDef: A dynamic layer is a layer from a map published through a map service whose appearance, such as labeling, layer order, and symbology, can be changed by the client.
terms.name: dynamic layer

terms.shortDef: An operational layer is a layer used by a map or a scene to visualize geographic data. Operational layers are displayed on top of a basemap layer.
terms.name: operational layer

terms.shortDef: An experience is a configurable web application created with ArcGIS Experience Builder that provides interactive maps, data, and media.
terms.name: experience

terms.shortDef: A composite symbol is a symbol that is a combination of two or more symbols. Each symbol can represent the same or a different aspect of a graphic or feature.
terms.name: composite symbol

terms.shortDef: A tier is either 1) a level in the MVC programming pattern; 2) in a utility network, a tier is part of the architectural structure of a subnetwork that helps to define its properties and restrictions.
terms.name: tier

terms.shortDef: Feature data is a general term for one or more features, which are records that represent real-world geographic entities, stored as a feature collection, feature layer, or hosted feature layer.
terms.name: feature data

terms.shortDef: An expression is a formula for calculating a value in a layer, using the Mapbox GL expression syntax.
terms.name: expression (Mapbox)

terms.shortDef: The raster analysis service is a service that can be used to perform operations on raster data such as pattern analysis, summarization, proximity analysis, data conversion and performing deep learning analysis.
terms.name: raster analysis service

terms.shortDef: A nonspatial table is a table that contains no geometry information.
terms.name: nonspatial table

terms.shortDef: GeoJSON is an open standard for representing geographic information in a JSON file. It is commonly used for sharing data between web services or manipulating vector data in the browser.
terms.name: geoJSON

terms.shortDef: A hosted imagery layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to access and manage the properties and settings of an image service.
terms.name: hosted imagery layer

terms.shortDef: A reference layer is a layer of information in a map that provides context to a location, such as labels for place-names, transportation routes, or other features of reference. Typically a reference layer is part of a basemap.
terms.name: reference layer

terms.shortDef: Geocoding is the process of converting text for an address or place to a complete address with a location.
terms.name: geocode

terms.shortDef: A vertex is a point that stands alone or composes part of a geometry.
terms.name: vertex

terms.shortDef: A trace is an action that analyzes the paths in a utility network and returns features based on connectivity or traversability from the specified starting points.
terms.name: trace

terms.shortDef: The geometry service is a service that performs operations on geometries such as creating, comparing, modifying, and projecting geographic shapes.
terms.name: geometry service

terms.shortDef: Advanced symbology is the set of conventions, rules, or encoding systems that define how to represent on a map geographic features or other items of interest (such as airplane routes) that are more complex than a simple point, line, or polygon.
terms.name: advanced symbology

terms.shortDef: Content is a collection of items in a portal that belong to a user, group, or organization.
terms.name: content

terms.shortDef: A canvas is a basemap specifically designed to give users a neutral format on which they can easily display data.
terms.name: canvas

terms.shortDef: A rule engine is a tool that assembles military symbols using data in the style file and rules from a provided military specification.
terms.name: rule engine

terms.shortDef: A layer in Mapbox GL JS is a visual element that displays data from a source.
terms.name: layer (Mapbox)

terms.shortDef: A hosted WFS layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings of an OGC WFS feature service.
terms.name: hosted wfs layer

terms.shortDef: The hydrology service is a location service that traces water flow and generates watersheds.
terms.name: hydrology service

terms.shortDef: The basemap styles service, also known as ArcGIS Basemap Styles service, is a location service hosted by Esri that provides access to vector tiles and map tiles for the world.
terms.name: basemap styles service

terms.shortDef: Map Viewer is a browser-based mapping tool that can view, create, and save web maps. It can also perform mapping, visualization, and spatial analysis operations.
terms.name: Map Viewer

terms.shortDef: A service geodatabase is a geodatabase used in ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps that connects to a feature service as a whole.
terms.name: service geodatabase

terms.shortDef: An authorization endpoint is an ArcGIS portal service endpoint that can be queried to request an authorization code. It is used to implement user authentication OAuth2.0 flows.
terms.name: authorization endpoint

terms.shortDef: A vector tile style is a JSON structure and accompanying resources that define how the contents of vector tiles are displayed in a client application.
terms.name: vector tile style

terms.shortDef: Geoprocessing is a GIS operation that is used to manipulate data. A typical geoprocessing operation takes an input dataset, performs an operation on that dataset, and then returns the result of the operation as an output dataset.
terms.name: geoprocessing

terms.shortDef: A callout is a container view that can be added over the map and anchored to a coordinate with a leader.
terms.name: callout

terms.shortDef: A hosted feature layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings of a spatially-enabled feature layer in a feature service.
terms.name: hosted feature layer

terms.shortDef: OAuth 2.0 is an industry standard protocol for authorization. It defines how to obtain and manage credentials for web, desktop, and mobile applications. It is supported by ArcGIS.
terms.name: OAuth 2.0

terms.shortDef: A simple relationship is a relationship between two tables in which features in the destination table are independent of features in the origin table.
terms.name: simple relationship

terms.shortDef: Offline-enabled is a setting in a web map or hosted layer item that allows it to be downloaded and used by offline apps.
terms.name: offline-enabled

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Maps SDK for JavaScript, previously known as ArcGIS API for JavaScript, is a developer product for building mapping and spatial analysis applications for the web.
terms.name: ArcGIS Maps SDK for JavaScript

terms.shortDef: A shapefile is a vector data storage format that contains geometry and attribute data for geographic features. It can also include spatial and non-spatial indexes.
terms.name: shapefile

terms.shortDef: The static basemap tiles service, also known as ArcGIS Static Basemap Tiles service, is a location service hosted by Esri that provides access to raster basemap tiles for the world.
terms.name: static basemap tiles service

terms.shortDef: A dirty area is a sublayer of a utility network that captures features that have been edited since the last topology network update / validation.
terms.name: dirty area

terms.shortDef: A KML node is an element definition within a KML document. A KML node can be a container (such as a folder with additional child nodes) or a geometry node (a node with an associated geometry).
terms.name: KML node

terms.shortDef: A camera defines the rendering viewpoint of a 3D scene in a scene view.
terms.name: camera

terms.shortDef: A geodetic measurement is any method of measuring geographic distance or area that uses a curved (nonplanar) surface to model the Earth.
terms.name: geodetic measurement

terms.shortDef: A Web feature service (WFS) is an Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) standard for feature services.
terms.name: web feature service

terms.shortDef: An item, also known as a content item, is a resource stored in a portal such as a web map, hosted layer, style, script tool, file, or notebook.
terms.name: item

terms.shortDef: A dashboard element is a visual component in ArcGIS Dashboards that displays data organized and curated from various sources like a hosted layer or web map in ArcGIS.
terms.name: dashboard element

terms.shortDef: A feature type consists of one or more templates for a feature stored in a feature service.
terms.name: feature type

terms.shortDef: A direct connection is a connection established from an ArcGIS client application or API to a geodatabase that uses a direct-connect database driver instead of connecting through an ArcSDE service.
terms.name: direct connection

terms.shortDef: A mosaic dataset is a grouping of raster data images into a single container for convenient display.
terms.name: mosaic dataset

terms.shortDef: A related feature is a feature in a table that has been associated with a feature in a different table using a key.
terms.name: related feature

terms.shortDef: A subtype feature layer is a feature layer that allows symbology and other layer properties to be set on a per-subtype basis.
terms.name: subtype feature layer

terms.shortDef: An token endpoint is an endpoint of a portal service that can be queried to request an access token. It is used to implement user authentication OAuth2.0 flows.
terms.name: token endpoint

terms.shortDef: A style is a definition describing how map content should be rendered in a map view. It is typically read from a service or a file.
terms.name: style

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS API for Python is a pythonic library for performing GIS visualization, analysis, data management, and GIS system administration tasks.
terms.name: ArcGIS API for Python

terms.shortDef: A size variable is a visual variable that defines the size of a symbol based on a numeric data value returned from a field or expression.
terms.name: size variable

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Online is a GIS mapping, analytics, data hosting, and content management software as a service (SaaS) product. It includes applications, tools, APIs, and location services for users and developers. It is subscription-based and requires an ArcGIS Online account.
terms.name: ArcGIS Online

terms.shortDef: An asset group is the main classification of a utility element. Each asset group is then divided into a collection of asset types.
terms.name: asset group

terms.shortDef: Keyhole Markup Language (KML) is an XML-based format that describes geographic entities. Developed and popularized for use with Google Earth, the KML specification is now maintained by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC).
terms.name: KML

terms.shortDef: OAuth credentials are an item that contains parameters required to implement user authentication or app authentication, including a client_id, client_secret, and redirect URIs. They are a type of developer credential.
terms.name: OAuth credentials

terms.shortDef: A widget is a UI component that supports user interaction or displays information about the data in a map or scene.
terms.name: widget

terms.shortDef: A system is a collection of assets that make up a public utility.
terms.name: system

terms.shortDef: Attributes are fields and values for a single feature or non-spatial record. They are typically stored in a database or service such as a feature service.
terms.name: attributes

terms.shortDef: An association is a relationship between two elements that is reflected in a utility network topology.
terms.name: association

terms.shortDef: The ArcGIS IPS Setup mobile app allows you to survey the spatial distribution of radio signals from Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) beacons or WiFi access points inside your building(s) to create reference positioning data; it can also test positioning accuracy once ArcGIS IPS is deployed.
terms.name: ArcGIS IPS Setup

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS REST JS is a collection of JavaScript modules that can access ArcGIS location services and ArcGIS Enterprise services.
terms.name: ArcGIS REST JS

terms.shortDef: An elevation layer is a layer that defines the ground height or the surface for a scene.
terms.name: elevation layer

terms.shortDef: A network source is a feature table whose features comprise one of a utility network's datasets.
terms.name: network source

terms.shortDef: Personal scope is a permission level for privileges. Personal scope privileges require additional account permissions and should only be used in personal applications and automation scripts.
terms.name: personal scope

terms.shortDef: A template is a pre-designed web application that is configurable and serves as a starting point for creating maps and applications.
terms.name: template

terms.shortDef: An origin is a point that defines the start of a route.
terms.name: origin

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS Online account, also known as an ArcGIS Organization account, is an identity associated with an ArcGIS Online subscription. It can be used to access ArcGIS tools and develop applications with ArcGIS location services for an organization.
terms.name: ArcGIS Online account

terms.shortDef: A distance composite scene symbol is a type of symbol that changes based on the distance, in meters, between the scene view's camera and the graphic or feature to which the symbol is assigned.
terms.name: distance composite scene symbol

terms.shortDef: A polygon is a type of geometry containing an array of rings and a spatial reference. Each ring contains an array of point coordinates, where the first and last point are the same.
terms.name: polygon

terms.shortDef: Standard scope is a permission level for privileges. Standard scope privileges can be used in any application including public applications.
terms.name: standard scope

terms.shortDef: A feature layer view, also known as a view, is a feature layer that only exposes a subset of the fields and data available in an existing feature layer (source).
terms.name: feature layer view

terms.shortDef: A tile package is a tiled layer that has been bundled into a single .tpk/.tpkx file. The file contains a tile cache of the data and metadata about the layer, packaged into a single, portable file.
terms.name: tile package

terms.shortDef: A map cache is a directory containing tiles of a map extent at specific levels.
terms.name: map cache

terms.shortDef: An isolation trace is a trace that is used to determine the minimum set of operable assets (point and line features) required to stop a utility network's resource from traveling / flowing, effectively isolating an area of the network.
terms.name: isolation trace

terms.shortDef: The Location Platform Dashboard is a dashboard in the ArcGIS Location Platform website used to manage billing, view developer credentials, and monitor layers and data service usage. It can only be accessed with an ArcGIS Location Platform account.
terms.name: Location Platform Dashboard

terms.shortDef: A location is a position or region (point, line, or polygon) on the earth's surface.
terms.name: location

terms.shortDef: A point scene layer is a type of layer that provides high-performing display point features in a scene view (3D view) based on scale, distance, and threshold parameters associated with a viewpoint.
terms.name: point scene layer

terms.shortDef: Notebooks is a Jupyter Notebook environment in ArcGIS that provides an interface for scripting, executing Python code, creating visualizations, and using data tools. Each notebook is stored as an item in a portal or .ipynb file locally.
terms.name: Notebooks

terms.shortDef: A portal service provides the functionality to securely create, access, and manage content, data services, users, and groups in a portal. The service can be hosted by Esri or in ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: portal service

terms.shortDef: A data layer is a layer that references geographic data from a file or a service and is used to visualize the data in a map or scene.
terms.name: data layer

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS Enterprise account is an identity for an instance of ArcGIS Enterprise. It can be used to access ArcGIS Enterprise tools, applications, and services, and to develop applications.
terms.name: ArcGIS Enterprise account

terms.shortDef: Offline data is data that is generated and downloaded from a feature service, vector tile service, or image tile service for use in offline applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: offline data

terms.shortDef: A data file is a stand-alone file containing geographic data that can be sideloaded on to a device. It is typically used in offline applications that never connect to a network.
terms.name: data file

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS account is an identity with a user type and set of privileges that can access specific ArcGIS products, tools, APIs, services, and resources. The main account types that can be used for development are an ArcGIS Location Platform account, ArcGIS Online account, and ArcGIS Enterprise account. ArcGIS Location Platform and ArcGIS Online accounts are also associated with a subscription.
terms.name: ArcGIS account

terms.shortDef: Subsurface refers to the area below the surface of the earth. In a 3D scene, you can map content located either above or below the earth's surface (or both), such as earthquakes, mineral deposits, wells, pipes, or geologic strata.
terms.name: subsurface

terms.shortDef: A scene view is a user interface that displays scene layers and graphics in 3D. It uses a camera to control the visible area of the scene and supports user interactions such as pan, zoom, tilt, and rotate.
terms.name: scene view

terms.shortDef: Mobile-friendly is a website or an application that is designed to work well and provide a user-friendly experience on mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets.
terms.name: mobile friendly

terms.shortDef: An extent is a bounding rectangle with points that delineate an area for a map or scene.
terms.name: extent

terms.shortDef: A renderer is a collection of rules and symbols used to display the data in a layer.
terms.name: renderer

terms.shortDef: A coordinate system is a reference framework consisting of a set of points, lines, or surfaces, and a set of rules, used to define the positions of points in space in two or three dimensions.
terms.name: coordinate system

terms.shortDef: A composite relationship is a relationship between two geodatabase tables in which each feature in the destination table is expected to be related to an origin feature.
terms.name: composite relationship

terms.shortDef: An annotation layer is a layer that can access and display text for features on a map.
terms.name: annotation layer

terms.shortDef: A Client API is a web, native, or scripting Application Programming Interface (including all ArcGIS, open source, and third-party APIs) that has mapping capabilities and can be used to access ArcGIS location services.
terms.name: client API

terms.shortDef: A web map is a map stored as a JSON object that defines properties such as the basemap layer, data layers, layer styles, and pop-up styles. Its JSON structure is defined by the web map specification.
terms.name: web map

terms.shortDef: A viewpoint is a set of parameters used to define a geographic area visible in a map or scene.
terms.name: viewpoint

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Dashboards is an app builder product that creates configurable dashboards to visualize data, communicate information, and analyze real-time data in a single screen.
terms.name: ArcGIS Dashboards

terms.shortDef: A basemap style is a set of visual properties, such as fill colors, viewing levels, and labels, that define how the visual elements in a vector tile basemap layer are displayed.
terms.name: basemap style

terms.shortDef: A connected trace is a utility network trace that begins at one or more starting points and spans outward radially along connected features. The trace stops when a barrier is encountered or there are no more connected features.
terms.name: connected trace

terms.shortDef: A coordinate is a value that denotes the location of a vertex. Coordinates can represent 2D (x,y) or 3D (x,y,z) space. The meaning of the x,y,z coordinates are determined by a coordinate system.
terms.name: coordinate

terms.shortDef: The on-demand workflow is a development pattern for building offline applications where the offline application defines an area of a web map to take offline.
terms.name: on-demand workflow

terms.shortDef: An attachment is a file, such as a photograph (for example, a .png file) or a document, that is associated with individual features in a geodatabase or feature layer.
terms.name: attachment

terms.shortDef: Geometry analysis is a type of client-side analysis that performs one or more spatial operations on a point, polyline, or polygon to solve a geometric problem.
terms.name: geometry analysis

terms.shortDef: An IPS aware map is a map that allows you to locate yourself indoors by displaying your current position on a map.
terms.name: IPS-aware map

terms.shortDef: An offline map area, also known as a preplanned map area, is an area in a web map used to create an offline map.
terms.name: offline map area

terms.shortDef: A structure network is a network representing features within a utility network that do not carry a resource, such as cabinets and poles.
terms.name: structure network

terms.shortDef: A feature set is an in-memory data structure that contains a collection of features. It is used by APIs such as ArcGIS Maps SDK for JavaScript, ArcGIS Arcade, and ArcGIS API for Python.
terms.name: feature set

terms.shortDef: A hosted image tile layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings of an image tile service.
terms.name: hosted image tile layer

terms.shortDef: A license string is a string of characters developers add to their application code to license their use of applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps and to unlock certain capabilities on the deployment device.
terms.name: license string

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS Location Platform account, formerly known as an ArcGIS Developer account, is an identity associated with an ArcGIS Location Platform subscription.
terms.name: ArcGIS Location Platform account

terms.shortDef: An integrated mesh layer is a layer that displays an integrated mesh in a 3D scene. Typically captured by an automated process for constructing 3D objects out of large sets of overlapping imagery, the result integrates the original input image information into a textured mesh.
terms.name: integrated mesh layer

terms.shortDef: An asset type is a class that refines a utility element's classification within an asset group. For example, a power transformer is an asset type of the transformer asset group within an electric device network.
terms.name: asset type

terms.shortDef: An offline application, also known as offline app, is an application that runs on a phone, tablet, laptop or desktop device with limited or no network connection. Offline applications are built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: offline application

terms.shortDef: An indoor positioning system is a system based on a network of devices (usually BLE or Wi-Fi) used to locate people or objects indoors, where other localization sources such as GPS lack precision or fail entirely.
terms.name: indoor positioning system

terms.shortDef: A map image layer is a data layer that can access and display map images that are created dynamically as users zoom or pan around a map view.
terms.name: map image layer

terms.shortDef: A symbol dictionary is a set of symbol primitives and a rule engine that allow developers to use military symbols in their applications. These symbols adhere to military symbol specifications such as MIL-STD-2525C.
terms.name: symbol dictionary

terms.shortDef: A Software Development Kit (SDK) is a collection of software development tools for building applications. They typically consist of an API, documentation, tools, and samples.
terms.name: SDK

terms.shortDef: Tools, also known as developer tools, are ArcGIS software applications such as portal and ArcGIS Pro that developers can use to prepare content and data for custom applications they are building.
terms.name: tools

terms.shortDef: Zoom level is a value that sets the scale for a map view or a scene view.
terms.name: zoom level

terms.shortDef: A dictionary renderer is a renderer that uses a style file generated in ArcGIS Pro from a rule engine and is used to display types of advanced symbology on a map, such as military symbology.
terms.name: dictionary renderer

terms.shortDef: A feature service is a data service that provides access to spatial and non-spatial data in feature layers, feature layer views, and tables.
terms.name: feature service

terms.shortDef: A feature template is a named set of default attribute values used to streamline feature creation.
terms.name: feature template

terms.shortDef: An image tile layer is a data layer that can access and display raster tile data provided by an image layer service.
terms.name: image tile layer

terms.shortDef: A wander extent is the factor of map extent within which a location symbol can move before triggering auto-panning to recenter the map on the current location.
terms.name: wander extent

terms.shortDef: Runtime components are a collection of files containing parts of ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps functionality, installed and used on a development machine and deployed with the apps created by developers.
terms.name: runtime components

terms.shortDef: A mobile scene package (MSPK) is a standalone file that contains one or more scene definitions, including the basemap layers, elevation layers, data layers, layer styles, and pop-up styles for use in offline applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: mobile scene package

terms.shortDef: Level of detail (LOD) is a scale level defined in a tiling scheme. It represents the zoom level value.
terms.name: level of detail

terms.shortDef: A mobile map package (MMPK) is a standalone file that contains one or more map definitions, including the basemap layers, data layers, layer styles, and pop-up styles for use in offline applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: mobile map package

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Enterprise services are services an organization can host in ArcGIS Enterprise. This includes map services, feature services, tile services, geometry services, geoprocessing services, spatial analysis services, and many others.
terms.name: ArcGIS Enterprise service

terms.shortDef: Local server is a lightweight GIS processor that supports an application built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: local server

terms.shortDef: A downstream trace is a trace in a sink (resource flow is toward the subnetwork controller) or source (resource flows away from or exits the controller) utility network that follows the flow of the resource.
terms.name: downstream trace

terms.shortDef: A place ID is an unique identifier for a place. You can use the ID with the places service to return additional attribute information such as name, address, description, contact information, website, social links, hours of operation, price ratings, and user ratings.
terms.name: place id

terms.shortDef: Utility network definition is the metadata in the UtilityDomainNetwork class used for a utility network's feature service. This class serves as the entry point to the metadata for all elements in the utility network.
terms.name: utility network definition

terms.shortDef: An opacity variable defines the opacity of a symbol based on a numeric data value returned from a field or expression. It is typically used to make features more or less prominent than others.
terms.name: opacity variable

terms.shortDef: A secure resource is any item or service in an ArcGIS that requires an ArcGIS account and authentication to access. Examples include ArcGIS Location Services, and items and data services in an ArcGIS portal.
terms.name: secure resource

terms.shortDef: Location services, also known as ArcGIS Location Services, are services with geospatial functionality and data hosted by Esri for developers. They include the ArcGIS Basemap Styles service, ArcGIS Static Basemap Tiles service, ArcGIS Places service, ArcGIS Geocoding service, ArcGIS Routing service, ArcGIS GeoEnrichment service, and ArcGIS Elevation service.
terms.name: location services

terms.shortDef: A destination table is a table that has been associated with an origin table using a key.
terms.name: destination table

terms.shortDef: Side-by-side development is a capability that allows developers to use different versions of the same API on the same machine.
terms.name: side-by-side development

terms.shortDef: An map tile package, formerly known as image tile package, is a read-only data file containing static, pre-rendered map tiles.
terms.name: map tile package

terms.shortDef: An item ID is a unique identifier representing a single item stored, managed, and accessed in a portal, such as a web map, hosted layer, or file.
terms.name: item ID

terms.shortDef: A vector tile layer is a data layer used to access and display tiled data and its corresponding styles.
terms.name: vector tile layer

terms.shortDef: Member is an individual with an ArcGIS account who can sign in, access tools and applications, and collaborate with other organization members in a portal.
terms.name: member

terms.shortDef: App authentication is a type of authentication that grants a short-lived access token based on an OAuth 2.0 client ID and client secret, authorizing an application to access ArcGIS services and items.
terms.name: app authentication

terms.shortDef: A web app is a mapping, analysis, or data-driven application that runs in a web browser. In most cases they are configurable and are hosted in ArcGIS.
terms.name: web app

terms.shortDef: A utility network is a feature service that represents a utility system, such as water, gas, or electricity. A utility network provides the capabilities to visualize, edit, and analyze utility assets and data.
terms.name: utility network

terms.shortDef: A label is text displayed with and associated with a graphic or feature.
terms.name: label

terms.shortDef: A device is nearly any kind of computer, including desktops, laptops, mobile phones, and tablets.
terms.name: device

terms.shortDef: A private application is an application developers create that requires users to sign in with an ArcGIS account. Private applications implement user authentication and are typically built for members of an organization.
terms.name: private application

terms.shortDef: Geodesic is the shortest distance between two points on the surface of a spheroid (also known as an ellipsoid). Any two points along a meridian form a geodesic line.
terms.name: geodesic

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Experience Builder is a highly configurable app builder product that creates immersive web apps by combining maps, data, and interactive widgets with little to no coding.
terms.name: ArcGIS Experience Builder

terms.shortDef: The ArcGIS Vector Tile Style Editor is a web-based application used to create, edit, and save a custom style for vector tile basemap layer.
terms.name: ArcGIS Vector Tile Style Editor

terms.shortDef: A hosted scene layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings for 3D data in a scene service.
terms.name: hosted scene layer

terms.shortDef: A stop is a single point along a route: it can be the origin, an intermediate stop, or destination.
terms.name: stop

terms.shortDef: A point cloud is a (usually) large collection of points in 3D space representing locations of points on real-world surfaces and objects, collected with a 3D scanning device such as lidar.
terms.name: point cloud

terms.shortDef: A basemap layer is a layer used to access and display data from a data source such as the basemap layer service, static basemap tiles service, or data service. It provides visual and geographic context for a map or scene and typically contains global data with administrative boundaries and place names.
terms.name: basemap layer

terms.shortDef: A polyline is a type of geometry containing ordered point coordinates and a spatial reference.
terms.name: polyline

terms.shortDef: Data management tools are ArcGIS software applications and functionality in portal and ArcGIS Pro that can be used by developers to create, manage, and edit content and data such as web maps, hosted layers, and data services for their applications.
terms.name: data management tools

terms.shortDef: The Data Collection Finder is a tool for exploring pre-defined categories of analysis variables available in the GeoEnrichment service that can be used as input for GeoEnrichment operations.
terms.name: Data Collection Finder

terms.shortDef: A Client ID is an identifier associated with an application that assists with client / server OAuth 2.0 authentication for ArcGIS client APIs.
terms.name: client ID

terms.shortDef: A point cloud scene layer is a scene layer that provides high-performing display of large volumes of symbolized and filtered point cloud data.
terms.name: point cloud scene layer

terms.shortDef: A subnetwork controller is a type of utility network feature from which a resource is delivered or collected, such as a circuit breaker (electric), town border stations (gas), or water towers (water).
terms.name: subnetwork controller

terms.shortDef: ARCore is a Google SDK that enables the development of augmented reality (AR) experiences.
terms.name: ARCore

terms.shortDef: Connected is the state of having a network connection, for example, to ArcGIS Online or ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: connected

terms.shortDef: A graphics overlay is a client-side, temporary container of graphics to display on a map view or scene view.
terms.name: graphics overlay

terms.shortDef: A public application is an application developers create that does not require users to sign in with an ArcGIS account. Public applications typically implement API key authentication or app authentication to authenticate requests to secure resources.
terms.name: public application

terms.shortDef: Identify is a query based on a point on a map or scene that is used to find feature, graphic, or raster cell data.
terms.name: identify

terms.shortDef: A geometry is a geometric shape, such as a point, polyline, or polygon, that contains one or more coordinates and a spatial reference.
terms.name: geometry

terms.shortDef: A filter barrier is a setting in a trace configuration that specifies when an isolation trace will stop for a specific category or network attribute.
terms.name: filter barrier

terms.shortDef: A basemap is a layer or collection of layers used to access and display data from a data source such as the basemap styles service. It provides visual and geographic context for a map or scene and typically contains global data with administrative boundaries and place names.
terms.name: basemap

terms.shortDef: A dashboard is configurable web application created with ArcGIS Dashboards that presents location-based analytics through interactive data visualizations on a single screen.
terms.name: dashboard

terms.shortDef: Pay-as-you-go refers to a type of billing where services are metered and you pay only for the services you use.
terms.name: pay-as-you-go

terms.shortDef: An instant app is a configurable web application created with templates in ArcGIS Instant Apps that displays maps and data and supports mapping workflows.
terms.name: instant app

terms.shortDef: A hosted map tile layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings of a map tile service.
terms.name: hosted map tile layer

terms.shortDef: With ArcGIS Indoors you can create and manage floor plan data in ArcGIS Pro and share floor-aware maps and services for use in web and native apps.
terms.name: ArcGIS Indoors

terms.shortDef: The field of view (FOV) is the amount of the world visible to a camera, usually measured in degrees.
terms.name: field of view

terms.shortDef: A story is a web application created with ArcGIS StoryMaps that contains digital narrative which combines interactive maps, multimedia content, and text to convey information or tell a story.
terms.name: story

terms.shortDef: Cross-platform development is the capability supported by a number of ArcGIS APIs that help developers write code with an API that can be used on multiple platforms and devices.
terms.name: cross-platform development

terms.shortDef: The sketch editor is a tool that allows users to interactively sketch geometries on a view.
terms.name: sketch editor

terms.shortDef: Transformation is the task of moving data between different geographic coordinate systems.
terms.name: transformation

terms.shortDef: Cross-platform deployment is the capability supported by several ArcGIS APIs that help developers write code and deploy applications to multiple platforms and devices.
terms.name: cross-platform deployment

terms.shortDef: A tile is an image, often a graphics file (such as a .jpg), typically stored in a directory known as a cache. The image is part of a set of tiles that, conceptually, are pieces of a bigger map.
terms.name: tile

terms.shortDef: A table is a non-spatial dataset in a feature service. All records in a table share the same set of fields.
terms.name: table

terms.shortDef: An item page is a web page in ArcGIS Online or the developer dashboard used to access and manage the properties for an item and the content it references such as a web map, hosted layer, or file.
terms.name: item page

terms.shortDef: A standard endpoint is a URL for an ArcGIS location service hosted in a global cloud infrastructure. This includes the basemap layer service, and most functionality available in the geocoding service and routing service.
terms.name: standard endpoint

terms.shortDef: Esri attribution is the requirement to display "Powered by Esri" text in all applications that use Esri technology including ArcGIS Maps SDKs, APIs, content, or services.
terms.name: Esri attribution

terms.shortDef: An origin feature is a feature in an origin table that is associated with a destination feature in a destination table.
terms.name: origin feature

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Maps SDKs are developer products for building mapping and spatial analysis applications for web browsers, native devices, and game engines.
terms.name: ArcGIS Maps SDKs

terms.shortDef: A mobile mosaic dataset is a SQLite database that allows developers to store, manage, view, and query small to vast collections of raster and image data.
terms.name: mobile mosaic dataset

terms.shortDef: A utility element is an entity in a utility network that corresponds to a feature or a part of a feature (for example, a terminal inside a device).
terms.name: utility element

terms.shortDef: User authentication is a type of authentication that allows users with an ArcGIS account to sign into an application and allow it to access ArcGIS content, services, and resources on their behalf. The typical authorization protocol used is OAuth2.0.
terms.name: user authentication

terms.shortDef: A great circle is a geodetic measurement that models the earth's surface as a sphere. A plane is formed by the start and end measure points and the center of the sphere.
terms.name: great circle

terms.shortDef: A route is a polyline that defines the best path between two or more points in a street network.
terms.name: route

terms.shortDef: A datum is a mathematical model of the Earth's shape used to measure locations (horizontal datums) and elevations (vertical datums).
terms.name: datum

terms.shortDef: A refresh token is a string obtained from user authentication that can be used to exchange an existing access token for a new one. The new access token has a new expiration date and possesses the same duration and level of authorization as the old token.
terms.name: refresh token

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS is the brand name for all of the desktop, server, and developer products and technologies offered by Esri.
terms.name: ArcGIS

terms.shortDef: A spatial table is a table containing geometry information; its features can be displayed on a map.
terms.name: spatial table

terms.shortDef: A destination is a point that defines the final stop in a route.
terms.name: destination

terms.shortDef: A service, also known as an ArcGIS service, is software that supports an ArcGIS REST API and provides geospatial functionality or data. A service can be hosted by Esri or in ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: service

terms.shortDef: App builder is an ArcGIS product that is used to create, configure, and deploy web applications using user interfaces, templates, and predefined software components.
terms.name: app builder

terms.shortDef: A screen overlay is an image in a KML layer that is anchored to the screen (as opposed to the map). Screen overlays are generally used to display things such as titles, company logos, legends, and so forth.
terms.name: screen overlay

terms.shortDef: An anonymous user is an individual who does not have an ArcGIS account and interacts with a user's content or an ArcGIS product, portal, or application. An anonymous user's identity is not authenticated, and they can only interact with ArcGIS resources that are public.
terms.name: anonymous user

terms.shortDef: An API key (legacy) is a permanent access token created before June 2024 used for accessing ArcGIS location services. API keys (legacy) have been replaced with API key credentials and can no longer be created.
terms.name: API key (legacy)

terms.shortDef: A pop-up is a visual element used to display data for features or graphics in a map.
terms.name: pop-up

terms.shortDef: A canvas layer is a basemap layer that provides a neutral background with minimal colors, labels, and features.
terms.name: canvas layer

terms.shortDef: A package is a set of items, such as a map and its referenced data, bundled into a single file on a local machine so that the items can be easily transferred from user to user or provisioned onto a device.
terms.name: package

terms.shortDef: Reverse geocoding is the process of converting a point to its nearest address or place.
terms.name: reverse geocode

terms.shortDef: Dynamic rendering mode is one of two modes used for rendering a graphics overlay. Dynamic rendering mode stores the entire graphic representation on the GPU, and individual graphic changes can be applied directly to the GPU state, resulting in better performance.
terms.name: dynamic rendering mode

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Marketplace is an online marketplace for customers to discover and acquire apps, content, and professional services from Esri's community of providers.
terms.name: ArcGIS Marketplace

terms.shortDef: Real-scale AR is a type of augmented reality (AR) in which scene content is overlaid onto its real-world physical position. Context aids, such as a basemap, are hidden, and the camera feed provides the context.
terms.name: real-scale AR

terms.shortDef: Branch versioning is a type of geodatabase versioning that works with the ArcGIS Enterprise Web GIS model. It uses a services-based architecture to allow multi-user editing workflows and long transaction scenarios via feature services.
terms.name: branch version

terms.shortDef: An offline map is a map area and its data content downloaded from an offline-enabled web map for use in offline applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: offline map

terms.shortDef: An origin table is a table that has been associated with a destination table, using a key.
terms.name: origin table

terms.shortDef: A destination feature is a feature in a destination table associated with an origin feature in an origin table.
terms.name: destination feature

terms.shortDef: A configurable app is a software program or application that can be created without writing code.
terms.name: configurable app

terms.shortDef: A class breaks renderer is a renderer that classifies numeric data into two or more ranges of values to create a visualization. Each class (or range) is defined by a lower and an upper value and a unique symbol.
terms.name: class breaks renderer

terms.shortDef: A map tile service, formerly known as image tile service, is a data service that provides access to static, pre-rendered image tiles.
terms.name: map tile service

terms.shortDef: A style file is a .stylx file created in ArcGIS Pro that contains symbol primitives, such as the symbol frame, lines that make up inner icons.
terms.name: style file

terms.shortDef: A barrier is a geometric feature that alters which streets a route can traverse in a street network.
terms.name: barrier

terms.shortDef: A Cartographic Information Model (CIM) symbol is an advanced, multi-layer symbol produced by ArcGIS Pro, client APIs, or developer code.
terms.name: CIM symbol

terms.shortDef: A data collection is pre-defined and categorized list of analysis variables (data field names) that are used by the GeoEnrichment service.
terms.name: data collection

terms.shortDef: A geopackage is an OGC spatial data storage format that can contain multiple datasets of geographic features, non-spatial tabular data, and raster data.
terms.name: geopackage

terms.shortDef: Visual variables are a set of parameters that define one or more properties of a renderer's symbols based on the numeric data value returned from a field or expression.
terms.name: visual variables

terms.shortDef: ARKit is an Apple SDK that enables the development of augmented reality (AR) experiences.
terms.name: ARKit

terms.shortDef: A view is a UI component that draws the layers in a map or scene and controls their extent (area) and geographic features.
terms.name: view

terms.shortDef: The Analysis Variable Finder is a tool for exploring the categories of data available in the GeoEnrichment service and for building a list of analysis variables that can be used as input for GeoEnrichment operations.
terms.name: Analysis Variable Finder

terms.shortDef: A by reference basemap is a basemap that already exists on a device. Using a by reference basemap can significantly reduce the time taken to download an offline map.
terms.name: by reference basemap

terms.shortDef: A group layer is a container for other layers and group layers.
terms.name: group layer

terms.shortDef: A fully offline app is a type of offline app built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps that is designed to work where network connectivity is entirely absent.
terms.name: fully offline app

terms.shortDef: Vertical coordinate system is a reference system that defines the location of z-values relative to a surface. The surface can be gravity related, such as a geoid, or a more regular surface like a spheroid or sphere.
terms.name: vertical coordinate system

terms.shortDef: Billboarding is a method used to display symbols in 3D scenes by positioning them vertically as 2D symbols and orienting them to always face the camera.
terms.name: billboarding

terms.shortDef: Provision is a means to provide data and other resources to an app by installing those resources with the app.
terms.name: provision

terms.shortDef: A point is a type of geometry containing a single set of x,y coordinates and a spatial reference.
terms.name: point

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS StoryMaps is an app builder product that creates interactive narratives by combining maps, multimedia content, and text to communicate stories in a visually engaging way.
terms.name: ArcGIS StoryMaps

terms.shortDef: A travel mode is the means of transportation, such as walking or driving, that defines how you can travel in a street network.
terms.name: travel mode

terms.shortDef: A map is a collection of layers that are displayed in 2D. It is typically composed of a basemap layer and data layers.
terms.name: map

terms.shortDef: A network is a set of features that are typically interconnected to each other within a region.
terms.name: network

terms.shortDef: Projection refers to a projected coordinate system based on a map projection such as transverse Mercator, Albers equal area, or Robinson, all of which project maps of the earth's spherical surface onto a 2D Cartesian coordinate plane.
terms.name: projection

terms.shortDef: A 3D visual analysis is a type of client-side analysis that calculates and displays spatial information derived from the terrain, buildings, and other 3D objects contained within a scene.
terms.name: 3D visual analysis

terms.shortDef: An organization a list of members from the same business, association, or entity who can sign in, access tools and applications, and collaborate with other members in a portal. All members have an ArcGIS account and are approved by an administrator to access the same portal.
terms.name: organization

terms.shortDef: A service area is a polygon representing the distance that can be reached within a specified length of time while traveling in a street network.
terms.name: service area

terms.shortDef: A unique value renderer is a renderer that defines a distinct symbol for each unique data value returned from a field or expression in a layer.
terms.name: unique value renderer

terms.shortDef: Data services, also known as hosted data services, are services created dynamically to store and provide access to your data in ArcGIS. Examples are feature services, vector tile services, map tile services, image services, and scene services.
terms.name: data services

terms.shortDef: Privileges are a set of permissions assigned to ArcGIS accounts, developer credentials, and applications that grant access to secure resources and functionality in ArcGIS.
terms.name: privileges

terms.shortDef: An ArcGIS user is a user who has an ArcGIS account and uses it to access an ArcGIS application, custom ArcGIS application, or a resource in an ArcGIS portal.
terms.name: ArcGIS user

terms.shortDef: An upstream trace is a trace in a sink (resource flow is toward the subnetwork controller) or source (resource flows away from or exits the controller) utility network that moves against the flow of the resource.
terms.name: upstream trace

terms.shortDef: Asynchronous is a style of programming that involves executing multiple tasks simultaneously rather than sequentially.
terms.name: asynchronous

terms.shortDef: API key credentials are an item that contains the parameters used to create and manage long-lived access tokens for API key authentication. They are a type of developer credential.
terms.name: API key credentials

terms.shortDef: A child layer is a sublayer that is a member of a group layer.
terms.name: child layer

terms.shortDef: A feature layer (client-side) is a data layer that can access and display features from a feature service that has the same type of geometry and attribute fields.
terms.name: feature layer (client-side)

terms.shortDef: Web map service (WMS) is an Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) standard that defines image-based map services.
terms.name: web map service

terms.shortDef: A model symbol is a type of marker symbol that uses a true three-dimensional graphical model to define the marker.
terms.name: model symbol

terms.shortDef: A graphic is a visual element composed of a geometry, symbol, and attributes that is displayed on a map or scene.
terms.name: graphic

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS IPS is an indoor positioning system that allows you to locate yourself and others inside a building in real time.
terms.name: ArcGIS IPS

terms.shortDef: A layer definition is a SQL WHERE clause for a feature layer that is used to select a subset of features from a feature service.
terms.name: layer definition

terms.shortDef: Feature analysis is a type of server-side analysis that uses the feature analysis service to perform geometric and analytic operations on feature data.
terms.name: feature analysis

terms.shortDef: A hosted layer is an item in a portal that contains the properties and settings for a hosted data service or a layer in a hosted data service.
terms.name: hosted layer

terms.shortDef: An item resource cache is a package of style resources downloaded from a vector tile style item in ArcGIS.
terms.name: item resource cache

terms.shortDef: A raster layer is a layer type that allows developers to display raster data in their applications.
terms.name: raster layer

terms.shortDef: Developer credentials are a type of item in a portal that contains parameters for authentication. There are two types of developer credentials: API key credentials and OAuth credentials.
terms.name: developer credentials

terms.shortDef: A web scene is a scene stored as a JSON object that defines properties such as the basemap layer, data layers, layer styles, and pop-up styles. Its JSON structure is defined by the web scene specification.
terms.name: web scene

terms.shortDef: A geoid is a hypothetical surface representing the form the earth's oceans would take if there were no land and the water could freely respond to the earth's gravitational and centrifugal forces.
terms.name: geoid

terms.shortDef: Augmented reality is a type of development pattern that provides end-users with an immersive 3D experience based on perceived device movement rather than manual keystroke, touch, or mouse-based interaction.
terms.name: augmented reality

terms.shortDef: An access token is an authorization string that provides secure access to content, data, and functionality in ArcGIS location services. The format is either an API key or an OAuth 2.0 token.
terms.name: access token

terms.shortDef: A raster is a matrix of cells (or pixels) organized into rows and columns (or a grid) where each cell contains a value representing information, such as temperature. Rasters include digital aerial photographs, imagery from satellites, digital pictures, and scanned maps.
terms.name: raster

terms.shortDef: A geodatabase is a spatial data storage format that can contain multiple datasets of geographic features and non-spatial tabular data, as well as attachments, field domain definitions, and relationships between layers/tables.
terms.name: geodatabase

terms.shortDef: A mobile basemap layer is a compressed data format that can be created from ArcGIS Pro when you share a map as a mobile map package.
terms.name: mobile basemap layer

terms.shortDef: Scene Viewer(™) is a browser-based mapping tool that can view, create, and save web scenes.
terms.name: Scene Viewer

terms.shortDef: Data attribution is the requirement to display the names of data source providers in all applications when accessing ArcGIS content, layers, or services.
terms.name: data attribution

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS REST APIs are the API specifications for all ArcGIS location services and ArcGIS Enterprise services. They define the operations, parameters, and structures required to make HTTPS requests.
terms.name: ArcGIS REST APIs

terms.shortDef: Analysis is a systematic examination of a problem that provides new information.
terms.name: analysis

terms.shortDef: Arcade is a lightweight and secure expression language used in ArcGIS products and APIs. Arcade expressions are commonly used to calculate or format field values for data-driven visualizations, labels, and popups. The expressions work against data stored in data services.
terms.name: Arcade

terms.shortDef: A direct request is a single HTTPS request to a service for a transaction that typically has a short duration.
terms.name: direct request

terms.shortDef: A subnetwork trace is a trace that discovers all participating features within a subnetwork.
terms.name: subnetwork trace

terms.shortDef: A data source is a service or file containing geographic data that is accessed by a data layer.
terms.name: data source

terms.shortDef: An enhanced endpoint is a URL for an ArcGIS location service hosted in a cloud infrastructure in the United States. They support all service functionality and additional levels of security compliance such as Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) and Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). Some endpoints also support long transactions.
terms.name: enhanced endpoint

terms.shortDef: A vector tile service is a data service that provides access to vector tile data and a style definition.
terms.name: vector tile service

terms.shortDef: Basemap services are location services hosted by Esri that provide tile data for basemap layers and maps. The main services are basemap styles service and static basemap tiles service.
terms.name: basemap services

terms.shortDef: A task is a class that provides methods to perform and manage asynchronous operations on online or offline data or services.
terms.name: task

terms.shortDef: A subnetwork is a subpart of a utility network tier, where all connected features are defined by the same subnetwork controller(s).
terms.name: subnetwork

terms.shortDef: A dynamic map service is a map that is redrawn by the server each time the user zooms or pans.
terms.name: dynamic map service

terms.shortDef: A terminal represents logical ports, entries, or exit locations on a single device or junction object within a utility network. Each port can flow in or out. Each device can contain many terminals, all of which can be interconnected.
terms.name: terminal

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Runtime APIs are the APIs included in ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps, and are used to build mapping, location, and GIS applications for desktops and mobile devices. Applications can be built for Android, iOS, Linux, macOS, and Windows.
terms.name: ArcGIS Runtime API

terms.shortDef: Scope is the permission level of a privilege. The level can be standard scope or personal scope.
terms.name: scope

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Enterprise is a GIS mapping, analytics, data hosting, and content management product that can be hosted on-premise or in a cloud infrastructure. It includes software, applications, tools, APIs, and services for users and developers.
terms.name: ArcGIS Enterprise

terms.shortDef: A mobile package is a stand-alone Mobile Map Package (MMPK) or Mobile Scene Package (MSPK) file for use in offline applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: mobile package

terms.shortDef: A GeoEnrichment service is a service that aggregates demographic data and local facts for locations around the world. It is used to provide insight about the people and places near a location. It is hosted by Esri as the ArcGIS GeoEnrichment service and can also be hosted in ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: GeoEnrichment service

terms.shortDef: A texture is an image file applied to a surface to assist in visual discrimination for the viewer and to impart a sense of 3D visual depth.
terms.name: texture

terms.shortDef: A multipoint is a type of geometry that contains an array of points and a spatial reference. Point coordinates are expressed as x,y values. Each coordinate can also optionally include a z value for height and/or a m value for measure (typically used in linear referencing).
terms.name: multipoint

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps, previously known as ArcGIS Runtime SDKs, are developer products for building mapping and spatial analysis applications for native devices.
terms.name: ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps

terms.shortDef: A spatial reference is a set of parameters, typically defined by a WKID, that define the coordinate system and spatial properties for geographic data. Applications use a spatial reference to correctly display the position of geographic data in a map or scene.
terms.name: spatial reference

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Location Platform, formerly known as ArcGIS Platform, is a Platform as a Service (PaaS) product that gives developers access to location services, APIs, and tools to build mapping and spatial analysis applications. It is subscription-based and requires an ArcGIS Location Platform account.
terms.name: ArcGIS Location Platform

terms.shortDef: A mobile data source is a data format used to build offline apps. The formats include offline maps, offline data, mobile packages, and data files.
terms.name: mobile data source

terms.shortDef: An authentication manager is a pre-built component developers can add to an app to assist with user authentication for secure resources, such as a secure layer.
terms.name: authentication manager

terms.shortDef: On-the-fly reprojection is a process that takes data stored in latitude and longitude format (unprojected data) and transforms its visual representation to match other projected datasets.
terms.name: on-the-fly reprojection

terms.shortDef: A hosted tiled imagery layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to access and manage the properties and settings of an image service.
terms.name: hosted tiled imagery layer

terms.shortDef: A map service is a data service that provides map images for display in a client application. The images can be rendered dynamically for a specific extent or pre-rendered and cached in a tile grid as static images. A map service can also provide access to underlying feature data used to create the map images.
terms.name: map service

terms.shortDef: A geoview is a base class for a map view and a scene view in ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: geoview

terms.shortDef: A feature service table is a data structure representing feature data retrieved from a feature service.
terms.name: feature service table

terms.shortDef: A scene layer is a data layer is used to access and display 3D data from a scene service.
terms.name: scene layer

terms.shortDef: A feature collection is a data structure containing one or more features that share the same geometry type and set of attributes.
terms.name: feature collection

terms.shortDef: An optimized route is the lowest cost path that visits all stops specified by the user in the most efficient order, regardless of the order in which they are provided.
terms.name: optimized route

terms.shortDef: A mobile geodatabase (.geodatabase) is a spatial data storage format in a single file on disk that can store, query, and manage spatial and nonspatial data. In applications built with the ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps, mobile geodatabases can be used in offline workflows when taking maps and features offline from services or in desktop-based scenarios as standalone mobile geodatabases from ArcGIS Pro.
terms.name: mobile geodatabase

terms.shortDef: Simple symbols are symbols that follow the web map specification. Developers can create and work with them through the simple symbol classes.
terms.name: simple symbol

terms.shortDef: A partially offline app is a type of offline app built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps that is designed to work where network connectivity is unreliable.
terms.name: partially offline app

terms.shortDef: Sharing level is the security setting assigned to an item in a portal that controls which users can access the resource. The sharing levels are Owner, Organization, Groups, and Everyone.
terms.name: sharing level

terms.shortDef: An API key is a long-lived access token created using API key credentials. They are valid for up to one year and are typically embedded directly into client applications.
terms.name: API key

terms.shortDef: Texture compression format is the compression format used to compress an image used as a texture.
terms.name: texture compression format

terms.shortDef: Static rendering mode is one of two modes used for rendering a graphics overlay. Static rendering mode is most suited for static graphics, complex geometries, and very large numbers of polygons.
terms.name: static rendering mode

terms.shortDef: An association graphic is a graphic that provides a visual representation of a structural or attachment association between two utility elements.
terms.name: association graphic

terms.shortDef: A map view is a user interface that displays map layers and graphics in 2D. It controls the area (extent) of the map that is visible and supports user interactions such as pan and zoom.
terms.name: map view

terms.shortDef: Dynamic labels are labels that are placed on a data layer based on user interactions, and whose text is generated dynamically based on a labeling expression stored with the data being labeled.
terms.name: dynamic labels

terms.shortDef: Offline is the state of having no network connection and applications cannot access ArcGIS Online or ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: offline

terms.shortDef: A related table is a table with a relationship to another table. The relationship is made possible by a key that is common to both tables. A related table can be either a spatial table or a non-spatial table.
terms.name: related table

terms.shortDef: A tile layer is a data layer that can access and display tiles (rectangular sections) into a continuous layer. The tiles are either raster image tiles or vector tiles that are generated into a tile cache before being made available for use.
terms.name: tile layer

terms.shortDef: A tile cache is a collection of tiles and metadata about how they should be used. A TPK contains a tile cache, for example.
terms.name: tile cache

terms.shortDef: A symbol defines the properties used to display a geometry or text.
terms.name: symbol

terms.shortDef: A GeoEnrichment study area is a location used for spatial analysis in the GeoEnrichment service.
terms.name: GeoEnrichment study area

terms.shortDef: A routing service is a service that uses network analysis and streets data to calculate the most effective path and turn-by-turn directions on a street network, optimize fleet routing and deliveries, find the closest facilities, calculate service areas, and more. It is hosted by Esri as the ArcGIS Routing service and can also be hosted in ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: routing service

terms.shortDef: A story block is a visual content element in a story that enhances the visual appearance and conveys information effectively. It helps with organizing and presenting a story in an engaging and visually appealing way.
terms.name: story block

terms.shortDef: The places service, also known as ArcGIS Places service, is a location service hosted by Esri that can search for businesses and geographic locations around the world and return detailed information about each place.
terms.name: places service

terms.shortDef: Feature subtypes categorize features in a feature set to enable per-subtype rendering configuration without the overhead of multiple layers.
terms.name: feature subtype

terms.shortDef: A choropleth map displays a set of pre-defined geographical areas proportionate to an aggregated summary of a specific, statistical variable within each area, such as the area's population density or per capita income.
terms.name: choropleth map

terms.shortDef: Loadable is a characteristic of a resource, such as a layer, map, or portal item, that allows developers to perform asynchronous operations while the resource loads.
terms.name: loadable

terms.shortDef: An image service is a data service that can store, process, analyze, and share raster data.
terms.name: image service

terms.shortDef: Planar measurements are measurements made on a flat surface. When using geographic coordinates, planar measurements must cut through the curved surface of the earth, causing the measurement to be shorter than the true distance.
terms.name: planar measurement

terms.shortDef: The offline packaging service is a service that can define, create, and update preplanned offline maps for a web map. Preplanned offline maps are hosted in ArcGIS, ready to be downloaded, and can be used without a network connection by applications built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: offline packaging service

terms.shortDef: A geoelement refers to any geographic element in a map or map view that can be identified by its location to return attribute information.
terms.name: geoelement

terms.shortDef: A geocoding service is a service that can search for addresses, place addresses, businesses, reverse geocode coordinates to addresses, provide suggestions for places, and perform bulk geocoding. It is hosted by Esri as the ArcGIS Geocoding service and can also be hosted in ArcGIS Enterprise.
terms.name: geocoding service

terms.shortDef: A legend is a table or chart associated with a map to indicate the meaning of the map's various symbols and layer representations.
terms.name: legend

terms.shortDef: Credits are the currency used by ArcGIS Online Organization accounts to account for data storage and location service consumption. Credits are consumed for specific transactions, such as accessing location services, and types of storage, such as storing features, performing analytics, and using premium content.
terms.name: credits

terms.shortDef: The feature analysis service, also known as the spatial analysis service, is a service that can be used to perform spatial analysis operations on feature data such as finding, comparing, summarizing, analyzing patterns, and calculating geometries.
terms.name: feature analysis service

terms.shortDef: Mobile-responsive is a website or an application that automatically adjusts the design and layout to fit different screen sizes and orientations providing the best viewing experience.
terms.name: mobile responsive

terms.shortDef: A scene service is a data service that provides access to large 3D datasets for scenes.
terms.name: scene service

terms.shortDef: A feature is a single record, also known as a row, that represents a real-world entity. It typically contains a geometry (point, multipoint, polyline, or polygon) and attributes but it can also contain just attributes.
terms.name: feature

terms.shortDef: A service feature table is a feature table created from a URL to an ArcGIS Feature service's layer or table.
terms.name: service feature table

terms.shortDef: A scene is a collection of layers that are displayed in 3D. It is typically composed of a basemap layer, data layers, and 3D data.
terms.name: scene

terms.shortDef: Raster analysis is a type of server-side analysis that uses the raster analysis service to perform geometric and analytic operations on raster data.
terms.name: raster analysis

terms.shortDef: API key authentication is a type of authentication that uses an API key to authenticate requests to ArcGIS services and secure portal items.
terms.name: API key authentication

terms.shortDef: A domain network is the primary classification of a utility network, representing the utility system type, such as electricity, gas, or water.
terms.name: domain network

terms.shortDef: An authorization code is a string that is used to obtain an access token associated with a user account. It is required in user authentication flows that adhere to the OAuth2.0 authorization_code grant type.
terms.name: authorization code

terms.shortDef: The ahead-of-time workflow, also known as the preplanned workflow, is a development pattern for building offline applications where offline map areas in a web map are used by the offline application.
terms.name: ahead-of-time workflow

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS portal, also known as a portal, is a website with applications and tools that can be used to create, manage, access, and share geospatial content and data. It supports security and authentication, developer credentials, content and data service management, user and group management, and site administration. A portal can be hosted in Esri's infrastructure or your own infrastructure.
terms.name: arcgis portal

terms.shortDef: Mobile-optimized is a website or an application that is specifically designed to provide the best possible user experience on mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets.
terms.name: mobile optimized

terms.shortDef: A hillshade is a layer data source with raster images that portrays hypothetical illumination of a surface by determining illumination values for each cell in a raster.
terms.name: hillshade

terms.shortDef: A color variable is a visual variable that defines the color of a symbol based on a numeric data value returned from a field or expression. If an expression is used, the color can be defined from a color ramp with a set of pre-defined color ranges.
terms.name: color variable

terms.shortDef: Runtime core refers to one or more client libraries (.dll or .so) that must be deployed with all apps built with ArcGIS Maps SDKs for Native Apps.
terms.name: runtime core

terms.shortDef: A place, also known as a point of interest (POI), is a location that represents a business, administrative entity, or geographic feature around the world. A place can also have attributes associated with it, such as a name, address, category, and ID.
terms.name: place

terms.shortDef: A sublayer is a classification, or member, of a group layer, and there can be many different kinds of sublayer. For example, a map service layer is a type of group layer that can contain one or more sub image layers.
terms.name: sublayer

terms.shortDef: Sideloading is the process of deploying a file or package to a device without using a network.
terms.name: sideload

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS.com is the website that ArcGIS Location Platform and ArcGIS Online developers use to sign in and access their portal. It can also be used to search for public items in other portals.
terms.name: ArcGIS.com

terms.shortDef: A multilayer symbol is a symbol type often used for complex symbols that require more than a single label. For example, military symbols require multiple adornments and text to display in predefined positions around a base symbol.
terms.name: multilayer symbol

terms.shortDef: A viewshed represents the locations visible from one or more specified points or lines.
terms.name: viewshed

terms.shortDef: The elevation service, also known as ArcGIS Elevation service, is a location service hosted by Esri that returns TopoBathy elevation values for a single location or multiple locations.
terms.name: elevation service

terms.shortDef: A source in Mapbox GL JS is a file or service that supplies data for a layer displayed in a map.
terms.name: source (Mapbox)

terms.shortDef: A job request is an HTTPS request to a service that starts a server-side operation (or job) with a long duration.
terms.name: job request

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Instant Apps is an app builder product that allows users to quickly create and share interactive web apps without any coding.
terms.name: ArcGIS Instant Apps

terms.shortDef: A hosted vector tile layer is a hosted layer (item) in a portal that is used to manage the properties and settings of a vector tile service.
terms.name: hosted vector tile layer

terms.shortDef: A simple renderer is a renderer that defines a single symbol used to display all features in a layer.
terms.name: simple renderer

terms.shortDef: Data apportionment is a geographic retrieval methodology used by the GeoEnrichment service to determine how data is gathered and summarized or aggregated for input features such as rings around a point and other polygons.
terms.name: data apportionment

terms.shortDef: A feature table is a database table of a single geometry type, such as point, line, or polygon, that stores features that conform to the schema of the table.
terms.name: feature table

terms.shortDef: The elevation analysis service is a location service that provides analysis on authoritative DEM data hosted and managed by Esri.
terms.name: elevation analysis service

terms.shortDef: A raster file is georeferenced bitmap data. It can be a single, standalone file or a collection of files that work together. Raster files are typically used in offline applications.
terms.name: raster file

terms.shortDef: Data enrichment is the process of using the GeoEnrichment service to enhance existing features with additional location-based data.
terms.name: data enrichment

terms.shortDef: OpenLayers is an Open Source JavaScript library used to make interactive maps.
terms.name: OpenLayers

terms.shortDef: A place category is a name and ID for a group of related places. There are four levels of place categories. Each category contains a categoryId, fullLabel, and parents (IDs).
terms.name: place category

terms.shortDef: A rotation variable is a visual variable that defines the rotation of a symbol based on a numeric data value returned from a field or expression. This value is typically used to rotate symbols that indicate directionality.
terms.name: rotation variable

terms.shortDef: ArcGIS Pro is a professional desktop GIS application that can explore, visualize, analyze, and manage 2D and 3D data.
terms.name: ArcGIS Pro

terms.shortDef: A locator is an ArcGIS dataset that stores address information and the rules for translating descriptions of places (such as street addresses or place names) into spatial data that can be displayed on a map.
terms.name: locator
